How does Plan B work?:

Plan B works like other birth control pills to prevent pregnancy. Plan B acts primarily by stopping the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation). It may prevent the union of sperm and egg (fertilization). IF FERTILIZATION DOES OCCUR, PLAN B MAY PREVENT A FERTILIZED EGG FROM ATTACHING TO THE WOMB (implantation). If a fertilized egg is implanted prior to taking Plan B, Plan B will not work.

The Plan B product information indicates that the main purpose of the drug is to prevent ovulation or fertilization, but the statement that fully reveals the danger of Plan B reads, “In addition, it may inhibit implantation (by altering the endometrium).” This means that Plan B can prevent a fertilized egg from attaching to a woman’s womb by causing the lining to thin. Plan B is thus denying the fertilized egg to obtain the nutrients it needs to survive. For anyone watching the video. Here are a few important things to know.
1. The brand Plan B is less effective on women who weigh 165lbs and its completely ineffective at 176lbs+
2. If you are over the 165lbs mark there are still good options like the pill Ella.
3. There are medications that can prevent plan B form working properly, so read the medication interaction list.
4. For anyone who has the money or the ability to get it done quickly, a copper IUD is a good option and you get a non hormonal birth control that can last up to 12 years.

Hey ASAPScience, found a bit of an error in your video there...you state that Plan B categorically does not act after fertilization...but the FDA says "Plan B works like other birth control pills to prevent pregnancy. Plan B acts primarily by stopping the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation). It may prevent the union of sperm and egg (fertilization). If fertilization does occur, Plan B may prevent a fertilized egg from attaching to the womb (implantation). If a fertilized egg is implanted prior to taking Plan B, Plan B will not work."

If a person believes that life begins at conception, and conception begins at fertilization, they would have concerns about using this method of contraception.

I copy some lines of an interesting post commenting a Planned Parenthood's facebook post

"Yesterday, Planned Parenthood posted this status on Facebook, claiming the morning-after pill “PREVENTS pregnancy, and won’t work if you’re already pregnant.”

This is a dishonest and scientifically inaccurate statement, because like any other
hormonal birth control method, emergency contraception can work one of three ways: suppressing ovulation (an egg isn’t released and sperm cannot fertilize the egg, so conception won’t occur); it can thicken cervical mucous (which acts as a barrier so sperm cannot fertilize the egg, and conception won’t occur); or it can render the uterus uninhabitable. 
When a woman uses hormonal contraceptives,  the lining of the womb is altered to try and prevent a newly-conceived human being from implanting if conception does happen to occur.  If this is the case, the tiny human being may be killed and lost during the woman’s menstrual cycle"

I think it needs to be said that this vid down plays some really important points: Plan-B does have major side effects. These include an increase risk of spontaneous abortions, ecotopic pregnancies, and fertility complications later in life. When taken at a younger age when the body is still developing these risks may be increased, so no, it's not safe for all ages. Taking Plan B multiple times is not a good idea either. Also, saying there are no studies on the effect Plan-B has on a fetus should bring up a red flag. My advice, regardless of age, sex, or whether you are sexual active, talk to your Dr. about Plan-B and contraceptives. Your health deserves more thought and consideration than what a youtube vid can provide.
